Package com.github.tommyettinger.anim8

Class PNG8

java.lang.Object
com.github.tommyettinger.anim8.PNG8
All Implemented Interfaces:
com.badlogic.gdx.utils.Disposable, AnimationWriter, Dithered
public class PNG8
extends java.lang.Object
implements AnimationWriter, Dithered, com.badlogic.gdx.utils.Disposable
PNG-8 encoder with compression; can write animated and non-animated PNG images in indexed-mode. An instance can be reused to encode multiple PNGs with minimal allocation.
You can configure the target palette and how this can dither colors via the palette field, which is a PaletteReducer object that defaults to null and can be reused. If you assign a PaletteReducer to palette, the methods PaletteReducer.exact(Color[]) or PaletteReducer.analyze(Pixmap) can be used to make the target palette match a specific set of colors or the colors in an existing image. If palette is null, this will compute a palette for each PNG that closely fits its set of given animation frames. If the palette isn't an exact match for the colors used in an animation (indexed mode has at most 256 colors), this will dither pixels so that from a distance, they look closer to the original colors. You can us PaletteReducer.setDitherStrength(float) to reduce (or increase) dither strength, typically between 0 and 2; the dithering algorithm used here by default is * based on blue noise and a quasi-random pattern (Dithered.DitherAlgorithm.BLUE_NOISE), but you can select alternatives * with setDitherAlgorithm(DitherAlgorithm), like a modified version of Jorge Jimenez' Gradient Interleaved * Noise using Dithered.DitherAlgorithm.GRADIENT_NOISE, or no dither at all with Dithered.DitherAlgorithm.NONE.
Note that for many cases where you write a non-animated PNG, you will want to use writePrecisely(FileHandle, Pixmap, boolean) instead of write(FileHandle, Pixmap, boolean, boolean), since writePrecisely will attempt to reproduce the exact colors if there are 256 colors or less in the Pixmap, and will automatically change to calling write() if there are more than 256 colors.
From LibGDX in the class PixmapIO, with modifications to support indexed-mode files, dithering, animation, etc.

    Modifier and Type Method Description
    static byte centralize​(byte v)  
    static void centralizePalette​(com.badlogic.gdx.files.FileHandle input, com.badlogic.gdx.files.FileHandle output)
    Given a FileHandle to read from and a FileHandle to write to, duplicates the input FileHandle and edits the red, green, and blue channels of each color in its palette (which is all colors in the image) by running each channel through a function (related to probit(double) that biases any channel values that aren't extreme toward the center of their range, and keeps extreme values (such as max green, or black) as they are.
    static void centralizePalette​(com.badlogic.gdx.files.FileHandle input, com.badlogic.gdx.files.FileHandle output, float amount)
    Given a FileHandle to read from and a FileHandle to write to, duplicates the input FileHandle and edits the red, green, and blue channels of each color in its palette (which is all colors in the image) by running each channel through a function (related to probit(double) that biases any channel values that aren't extreme toward the center of their range, and keeps extreme values (such as max green, or black) as they are.

    Should probably be done explicitly; finalize() has been scheduled for removal from the JVM.
    static void editPalette​(com.badlogic.gdx.files.FileHandle input, com.badlogic.gdx.files.FileHandle output, com.badlogic.gdx.math.Interpolation editor)
    Given a FileHandle to read from and a FileHandle to write to, duplicates the input FileHandle and edits the red, green, and blue channels of each color in its palette (which is all colors in the image) by converting them to a 0.0-1.0 range and giving that to editor.

    static double probit​(double d)
    A way of taking a double in the (0.0, 1.0) range and mapping it to a Gaussian or normal distribution, so high inputs correspond to high outputs, and similarly for the low range.

    • write

      public void write​(com.badlogic.gdx.files.FileHandle file, com.badlogic.gdx.graphics.Pixmap pixmap)
      Writes the given Pixmap to the requested FileHandle, computing an 8-bit palette from the most common colors in pixmap. If there are 256 or less colors and none are transparent, this will use 256 colors in its palette exactly with no transparent entry, but if there are more than 256 colors or any are transparent, then one color will be used for "fully transparent" and 255 opaque colors will be used.
      Parameters:
      file - a FileHandle that must be writable, and will have the given Pixmap written as a PNG-8 image
      pixmap - a Pixmap to write to the given file

    • write

      public void write​(com.badlogic.gdx.files.FileHandle file, com.badlogic.gdx.graphics.Pixmap pixmap, boolean computePalette)
      Writes the given Pixmap to the requested FileHandle, optionally computing an 8-bit palette from the most common colors in pixmap. When computePalette is true, if there are 256 or less colors and none are transparent, this will use 256 colors in its palette exactly with no transparent entry, but if there are more than 256 colors or any are transparent, then one color will be used for "fully transparent" and 255 opaque colors will be used. When computePalette is false, this uses the last palette this had computed, or the 256-color "Haltonic" palette if no palette had been computed yet.
      Parameters:
      file - a FileHandle that must be writable, and will have the given Pixmap written as a PNG-8 image
      pixmap - a Pixmap to write to the given file
      computePalette - if true, this will analyze the Pixmap and use the most common colors

    • write

      public void write​(com.badlogic.gdx.files.FileHandle file, com.badlogic.gdx.graphics.Pixmap pixmap, boolean computePalette, boolean dither)
      Writes the pixmap to the stream without closing the stream, optionally computing an 8-bit palette from the given Pixmap. If palette is null (the default unless it has been assigned a PaletteReducer value), this will compute a palette from the given Pixmap regardless of computePalette. Optionally dithers the result if dither is true.
      Parameters:
      file - a FileHandle that must be writable, and will have the given Pixmap written as a PNG-8 image
      pixmap - a Pixmap to write to the given output stream
      computePalette - if true, this will analyze the Pixmap and use the most common colors
      dither - true if this should dither colors that can't be represented exactly

    • write

      public void write​(com.badlogic.gdx.files.FileHandle file, com.badlogic.gdx.graphics.Pixmap pixmap, boolean computePalette, boolean dither, int threshold)
      Writes the pixmap to the stream without closing the stream, optionally computing an 8-bit palette from the given Pixmap. If palette is null (the default unless it has been assigned a PaletteReducer value), this will compute a palette from the given Pixmap regardless of computePalette. Uses the given threshold while analyzing the palette if this needs to compute a palette; threshold values can be as low as 0 to try to use as many colors as possible (prefer writePrecisely(FileHandle, Pixmap, boolean, int) for that, though) and can range up to very high numbers if very few colors should be used; usually threshold is from 100 to 800. Optionally dithers the result if dither is true.
      Parameters:
      file - a FileHandle that must be writable, and will have the given Pixmap written as a PNG-8 image
      pixmap - a Pixmap to write to the given output stream
      computePalette - if true, this will analyze the Pixmap and use the most common colors
      dither - true if this should dither colors that can't be represented exactly
      threshold - the analysis threshold to use if computePalette is true (min 0, practical max is over 100000)

    • write

      public void write​(java.io.OutputStream output, com.badlogic.gdx.graphics.Pixmap pixmap)
      Writes the pixmap to the stream without closing the stream and computes an 8-bit palette from the Pixmap.
      Parameters:
      output - an OutputStream that will not be closed
      pixmap - a Pixmap to write to the given output stream

      Parameters:
      output - an OutputStream that will not be closed
      pixmap - a Pixmap to write to the given output stream
      computePalette - if true, this will analyze the Pixmap and use the most common colors

      public void write​(java.io.OutputStream output, com.badlogic.gdx.graphics.Pixmap pixmap, boolean computePalette, boolean dither, int threshold)
      Writes the pixmap to the stream without closing the stream, optionally computing an 8-bit palette from the given Pixmap. If palette is null (the default unless it has been assigned a PaletteReducer value), this will compute a palette from the given Pixmap regardless of computePalette.
      Parameters:

      pixmap - a Pixmap to write to the given output stream
      computePalette - if true, this will analyze the Pixmap and use the most common colors
      dither - true if this should dither colors that can't be represented exactly
      threshold - the analysis threshold to use if computePalette is true (min 0, practical max is over 100000)

    • writePrecisely

      public void writePrecisely​(com.badlogic.gdx.files.FileHandle file, com.badlogic.gdx.graphics.Pixmap pixmap, boolean ditherFallback)
      Attempts to write the given Pixmap exactly as a PNG-8 image to file; this attempt will only succeed if there are no more than 256 colors in the Pixmap (treating all partially transparent colors as fully transparent). If the attempt fails, this falls back to calling write(FileHandle, Pixmap, boolean, boolean), which can dither the image to use no more than 255 colors (plus fully transparent) based on ditherFallback and will always analyze the Pixmap to get an accurate-enough palette. The write() methods in this class that don't have "Precise" in the name will reduce the color depth somewhat, but this will keep the non-alpha components of colors exactly. For full precision on any color count, use PixmapIO.PNG, or AnimatedPNG for animations.
      Parameters:
      file - a FileHandle that must be writable, and will have the given Pixmap written as a PNG-8 image
      pixmap - a Pixmap to write to the given output stream
      ditherFallback - if the Pixmap contains too many colors, this determines whether it will dither the output

    • writePrecisely

      public void writePrecisely​(com.badlogic.gdx.files.FileHandle file, com.badlogic.gdx.graphics.Pixmap pixmap, boolean ditherFallback, int threshold)
      Attempts to write the given Pixmap exactly as a PNG-8 image to file; this attempt will only succeed if there are no more than 256 colors in the Pixmap (treating all partially transparent colors as fully transparent). If the attempt fails, this falls back to calling write(FileHandle, Pixmap, boolean, boolean), which can dither the image to use no more than 255 colors (plus fully transparent) based on ditherFallback and will always analyze the Pixmap to get an accurate-enough palette, using the given threshold for analysis (which is typically between 1 and 1000, and most often near 200-400). The write() methods in this class that don't have "Precise" in the name will reduce the color depth somewhat, but this will keep the non-alpha components of colors exactly. For full precision on any color count, use PixmapIO.PNG, or AnimatedPNG for animations.
      Parameters:
      file - a FileHandle that must be writable, and will have the given Pixmap written as a PNG-8 image
      pixmap - a Pixmap to write to the given output stream
      ditherFallback - if the Pixmap contains too many colors, this determines whether it will dither the output
      threshold - the analysis threshold to use if there are too many colors (min 0, practical max is over 100000)

    • writePrecisely

      public void writePrecisely​(com.badlogic.gdx.files.FileHandle file, com.badlogic.gdx.graphics.Pixmap pixmap, int[] exactPalette, boolean ditherFallback, int threshold)
      Attempts to write the given Pixmap exactly as a PNG-8 image to output; this attempt will only succeed if there are no more than 256 colors in the Pixmap (treating all partially transparent colors as fully transparent). If the colors in the Pixmap can be accurately represented by some or all of exactPalette (and it is non-null), then that palette will be used in full and in order. If exactPalette is null, this scans through all the colors in pixmap, using the full set of colors if there are 256 or less (including transparent, if present), or if there are too many colors, this falls back to calling write(OutputStream, Pixmap, boolean, boolean), which can dither the image to use no more than 255 colors (plus fully transparent) based on ditherFallback and will always analyze the Pixmap to get an accurate-enough palette, using the given threshold for analysis (which is typically between 1 and 1000, and most often near 200-400). The dither algorithm can be configured with setDitherAlgorithm(DitherAlgorithm), if it gets used at all. The write() methods in this class that don't have "Precise" in the name will reduce the color depth somewhat, but this will keep the non-alpha components of colors exactly. For full precision on any color count, use PixmapIO.PNG, or AnimatedPNG for animations.
      Parameters:
      file - a FileHandle that must be writable, and will have the given Pixmap written as a PNG-8 image
      pixmap - a Pixmap to write to the given output stream
      exactPalette - if non-null, will try to use this palette exactly, in order and including unused colors
      ditherFallback - if the Pixmap contains too many colors, this determines whether it will dither the output
      threshold - the analysis threshold to use if there are too many colors (min 0, practical max is over 100000)

    • writePrecisely

      public void writePrecisely​(java.io.OutputStream output, com.badlogic.gdx.graphics.Pixmap pixmap, boolean ditherFallback)
      Attempts to write the given Pixmap exactly as a PNG-8 image to output; this attempt will only succeed if there are no more than 256 colors in the Pixmap (treating all partially transparent colors as fully transparent). If the attempt fails, this falls back to calling write(OutputStream, Pixmap, boolean, boolean), which can dither the image to use no more than 255 colors (plus fully transparent) based on ditherFallback and will always analyze the Pixmap to get an accurate-enough palette. The write() methods in this class that don't have "Precise" in the name will reduce the color depth somewhat, but this will keep the non-alpha components of colors exactly. For full precision on any color count, use PixmapIO.PNG, or AnimatedPNG for animations.
      Parameters:
      output - an OutputStream that will not be closed
      pixmap - a Pixmap to write to the given output stream
      ditherFallback - if the Pixmap contains too many colors, this determines whether it will dither the output

    • writePrecisely

      public void writePrecisely​(java.io.OutputStream output, com.badlogic.gdx.graphics.Pixmap pixmap, boolean ditherFallback, int threshold)
      Attempts to write the given Pixmap exactly as a PNG-8 image to output; this attempt will only succeed if there are no more than 256 colors in the Pixmap (treating all partially transparent colors as fully transparent). If the attempt fails, this falls back to calling write(OutputStream, Pixmap, boolean, boolean), which can dither the image to use no more than 255 colors (plus fully transparent) based on ditherFallback and will always analyze the Pixmap to get an accurate-enough palette, using the given threshold for analysis (which is typically between 1 and 1000, and most often near 200-400). The write() methods in this class that don't have "Precise" in the name will reduce the color depth somewhat, but this will keep the non-alpha components of colors exactly. For full precision on any color count, use PixmapIO.PNG, or AnimatedPNG for animations.
      Parameters:
      output - an OutputStream that will not be closed
      pixmap - a Pixmap to write to the given output stream
      ditherFallback - if the Pixmap contains too many colors, this determines whether it will dither the output
      threshold - the analysis threshold to use if there are too many colors (min 0, practical max is over 100000)

    • writePrecisely

      public void writePrecisely​(java.io.OutputStream output, com.badlogic.gdx.graphics.Pixmap pixmap, int[] exactPalette, boolean ditherFallback, int threshold)
      Attempts to write the given Pixmap exactly as a PNG-8 image to output; this attempt will only succeed if there are no more than 256 colors in the Pixmap (treating all partially transparent colors as fully transparent). If the colors in the Pixmap can be accurately represented by some or all of exactPalette (and it is non-null), then that palette will be used in full and in order. If exactPalette is null, this scans through all the colors in pixmap, using the full set of colors if there are 256 or less (including transparent, if present), or if there are too many colors, this falls back to calling write(OutputStream, Pixmap, boolean, boolean), which can dither the image to use no more than 255 colors (plus fully transparent) based on ditherFallback and will always analyze the Pixmap to get an accurate-enough palette, using the given threshold for analysis (which is typically between 1 and 1000, and most often near 200-400). The dither algorithm can be configured with setDitherAlgorithm(DitherAlgorithm), if it gets used at all. The write() methods in this class that don't have "Precise" in the name will reduce the color depth somewhat, but this will keep the non-alpha components of colors exactly. For full precision on any color count, use PixmapIO.PNG, or AnimatedPNG for animations.
      Parameters:
      output - an OutputStream that will not be closed
      pixmap - a Pixmap to write to the given output stream
      exactPalette - if non-null, will try to use this palette exactly, in order and including unused colors
      ditherFallback - if the Pixmap contains too many colors, this determines whether it will dither the output
      threshold - the analysis threshold to use if there are too many colors (min 0, practical max is over 100000)

    • writePreciseSection

      public void writePreciseSection​(com.badlogic.gdx.files.FileHandle file, com.badlogic.gdx.graphics.Pixmap pixmap, int[] exactPalette, int startX, int startY, int width, int height)
      Attempts to write a rectangular section of the given Pixmap exactly as a PNG-8 image to file; this attempt will only succeed if there are no more than 256 colors in the Pixmap (treating all partially transparent colors as fully transparent). If the attempt fails, this will throw an IllegalArgumentException. The write() methods in this class that don't have "Precise" in the name will reduce the color depth somewhat, but this will keep the non-alpha components of colors exactly. For full precision on any color count, use PixmapIO.PNG, or AnimatedPNG for animations.
      Parameters:
      file - a FileHandle that must be writable, and will have the given Pixmap written as a PNG-8 image
      pixmap - a Pixmap to write to the given output stream
      exactPalette - a palette with no more than 256 RGBA8888 ints in it; the colors will be used exactly if possible
      startX - start x-coordinate of the section in pixmap
      startY - start y-coordinate of the section in pixmap
      width - width of the section, in pixels
      height - height of the section, in pixels

    • writePreciseSection

If the attempt fails, this will throw an IllegalArgumentException. The write() methods in this class that don't have "Precise" in the name will reduce the color depth somewhat, but this will keep the non-alpha components of colors exactly. For full precision on any color count, use PixmapIO.PNG, or AnimatedPNG for animations.

    • write

      public void write​(com.badlogic.gdx.files.FileHandle file, com.badlogic.gdx.utils.Array<com.badlogic.gdx.graphics.Pixmap> frames)
      Writes the given Pixmaps to the requested FileHandle at 30 frames per second. If palette is null (the default unless it has been assigned a PaletteReducer value), this will compute a palette from all of the frames given. Otherwise, this uses the colors already in palette. Uses getDitherAlgorithm() to determine how to dither.
      Specified by:
      write in interface AnimationWriter
      Parameters:
      file - a FileHandle that must be writable, and will have the given Pixmap written as a PNG-8 image
      frames - a Pixmap Array to write as a sequence of frames to the given output stream

      public void write​(com.badlogic.gdx.files.FileHandle file, com.badlogic.gdx.utils.Array<com.badlogic.gdx.graphics.Pixmap> frames, int fps)
      Writes the given Pixmaps to the requested FileHandle at the requested frames per second. If palette is null (the default unless it has been assigned a PaletteReducer value), this will compute a palette from all of the frames given. Otherwise, this uses the colors already in palette. Uses getDitherAlgorithm() to determine how to dither.

    • write

      public void write​(com.badlogic.gdx.files.FileHandle file, com.badlogic.gdx.utils.Array<com.badlogic.gdx.graphics.Pixmap> frames, int fps, boolean dither)
      Writes the Pixmaps to the stream without closing the stream, optionally computing an 8-bit palette from the given Pixmap. If palette is null (the default unless it has been assigned a PaletteReducer value), this will compute a palette from all of the frames given. Otherwise, this uses the colors already in palette. Optionally dithers the result if dither is true, using the dither algorithm selected with setDitherAlgorithm(DitherAlgorithm) (or Dithered.DitherAlgorithm.PATTERN if not set).
      Parameters:
      file - a FileHandle that must be writable, and will have the given Pixmap written as a PNG-8 image
      frames - a Pixmap Array to write as a sequence of frames to the given output stream
      fps - how many frames per second the animation should run at
      dither - true if this should use getDitherAlgorithm() to dither; false to not dither

    • write

      public void write​(java.io.OutputStream output, com.badlogic.gdx.utils.Array<com.badlogic.gdx.graphics.Pixmap> frames, int fps, boolean dither)
      Writes the Pixmaps to the stream without closing the stream, optionally computing an 8-bit palette from the given Pixmaps. If palette is null (the default unless it has been assigned a PaletteReducer value), this will compute a palette from all of the frames given. Otherwise, this uses the colors already in palette. Optionally dithers the result if dither is true, using the dither algorithm selected with setDitherAlgorithm(DitherAlgorithm) (or Dithered.DitherAlgorithm.PATTERN if not set).
      Parameters:
      output - an OutputStream that will not be closed
      frames - a Pixmap Array to write as a sequence of frames to the given output stream
      fps - how many frames per second the animation should run at
      dither - true if this should use getDitherAlgorithm() to dither; false to not dither

    • readChunks

      protected static com.badlogic.gdx.utils.OrderedMap<java.lang.String,​byte[]> readChunks​(java.io.InputStream inStream) throws java.io.IOException

      inStream - an input stream to read from; will be closed at the end of this method

      Throws:
      java.io.IOException - if the file is not a PNG or is extremely long

    • swapPalette

      public static void swapPalette​(com.badlogic.gdx.files.FileHandle input, com.badlogic.gdx.files.FileHandle output, int[] palette)
      Given a FileHandle to read from and a FileHandle to write to, duplicates the input FileHandle and changes its palette (in full and in order) to exactly match palette. This is only likely to work if the input file was written with the same palette order, such as by specifying an exactPalette in writePrecisely(FileHandle, Pixmap, int[], boolean, int) where that exactPalette has similar colors at each palette index to palette.
      Parameters:
      input - FileHandle to read from that should have a similar palette (and very similar order) to palette
      output - FileHandle that should be writable and empty
      palette - RGBA8888 color array

    • editPalette

      public static void editPalette​(com.badlogic.gdx.files.FileHandle input, com.badlogic.gdx.files.FileHandle output, com.badlogic.gdx.math.Interpolation editor)
      Given a FileHandle to read from and a FileHandle to write to, duplicates the input FileHandle and edits the red, green, and blue channels of each color in its palette (which is all colors in the image) by converting them to a 0.0-1.0 range and giving that to editor. The libGDX wiki page on Interpolation has valuable info.
      Parameters:
      input - FileHandle to read from that should contain an indexed-mode PNG (such as one this class wrote)
      output - FileHandle that should be writable and empty
      editor - an Interpolation, such as Interpolation.circleOut (which brightens all but the darkest areas)

    • centralizePalette

      public static void centralizePalette​(com.badlogic.gdx.files.FileHandle input, com.badlogic.gdx.files.FileHandle output)
      Given a FileHandle to read from and a FileHandle to write to, duplicates the input FileHandle and edits the red, green, and blue channels of each color in its palette (which is all colors in the image) by running each channel through a function (related to probit(double) that biases any channel values that aren't extreme toward the center of their range, and keeps extreme values (such as max green, or black) as they are.
      Parameters:
      input - FileHandle to read from that should contain an indexed-mode PNG (such as one this class wrote)
      output - FileHandle that should be writable and empty

    • centralizePalette

      public static void centralizePalette​(com.badlogic.gdx.files.FileHandle input, com.badlogic.gdx.files.FileHandle output, float amount)
      Given a FileHandle to read from and a FileHandle to write to, duplicates the input FileHandle and edits the red, green, and blue channels of each color in its palette (which is all colors in the image) by running each channel through a function (related to probit(double) that biases any channel values that aren't extreme toward the center of their range, and keeps extreme values (such as max green, or black) as they are. This takes an amount parameter, between 0.0 and 1.0, that controls how much of the centralized effect to use (higher amount means more centralized colors).
      Parameters:
      input - FileHandle to read from that should contain an indexed-mode PNG (such as one this class wrote)
      output - FileHandle that should be writable and empty
      amount - how much this should use of the centralizing effect, from 0.0 (no centralization) to 1.0 (full)

    • centralize

      public static byte centralize​(byte v)

    • probit

      public static double probit​(double d)
      A way of taking a double in the (0.0, 1.0) range and mapping it to a Gaussian or normal distribution, so high inputs correspond to high outputs, and similarly for the low range. This is centered on 0.0 and its standard deviation seems to be 1.0 (the same as Random.nextGaussian()). If this is given an input of 0.0 or less, it returns -38.5, which is slightly less than the result when given Double.MIN_VALUE. If it is given an input of 1.0 or more, it returns 38.5, which is significantly larger than the result when given the largest double less than 1.0 (this value is further from 1.0 than Double.MIN_VALUE is from 0.0). If given Double.NaN, it returns whatever Math.copySign(double, double) returns for the arguments 38.5, Double.NaN, which is implementation-dependent. It uses an algorithm by Peter John Acklam, as implemented by Sherali Karimov. Original source. Information on the algorithm. Wikipedia's page on the probit function may help, but is more likely to just be confusing.
      Acklam's algorithm and Karimov's implementation are both quite fast. This appears faster than generating Gaussian-distributed numbers using either the Box-Muller Transform or Marsaglia's Polar Method, though it isn't as precise and can't produce as extreme min and max results in the extreme cases they should appear. If given a typical uniform random double that's exclusive on 1.0, it won't produce a result higher than 8.209536145151493, and will only produce results of at least -8.209536145151493 if 0.0 is excluded from the inputs (if 0.0 is an input, the result is 38.5). A chief advantage of using this with a random number generator is that it only requires one random double to obtain one Gaussian value; Random.nextGaussian() generates at least two random doubles for each two Gaussian values, but may rarely require much more random generation.
      Parameters:
      d - should be between 0 and 1, exclusive, but other values are tolerated
      Returns:
      a normal-distributed double centered on 0.0; all results will be between -38.5 and 38.5, both inclusive
